JobPositionInformation.PositionTitle: Senior Development Engineer for Aero-Elastic Tool Development
JobPositionInformation.Purpose:
The Department of Wind and Energy Systems at DTU is internationally recognized for its aero-elastic software and methodologies for both wind turbines and farms. We are expanding and improving our toolchain and are seeking a Senior Develompent Engineer to make a significant contribution to improvement of existing tools such as HAWC2 which are used both in our internal research and by external clients. In close collaboration with scientific and technical colleagues, you will have a direct impact on developing new generation of tools with a strengthened focus on wind farm modelling through new wake inflow models and tailored farm driver turbine models.

The position is in the Response, Aero-elasticity, Control and Hydrodynamics (REC) section located at our Risø campus. REC focuses on modelling and analysis of loads and dynamics, aeroelastic stability, and control of both land-based and offshore, including floating, wind turbines and implements its research in software tools and in courses to the benefit of the wind energy community in general. We have high focus on validation against measurements too. This is a highly multi-disciplinary issue involving modelling of the non-stationary inflow field, aerodynamics, structural dynamics, structural stability and control.

The job
This position's primary focus is to work closely with researchers and development engineers to provide software development knowledge and best practices and convert prototypes and ideas into efficient codes that benefit the wind energy community. The work involves five main areas of focus:
  • Further development, testing and support of DTU Wind Energy's core aeroelastic software HAWC2 including interfacing with other tools within DTU Wind's toolchain;
  • Development of HAWC2 ecosystem software including pre- and post-processing tools, scripting tools for supporting use in high performance computing environments, visualization tools and more;
  • Implement and promote software development best practices in teams of software developers and research scientists working in the department.

The successful candidate will be expected to collaborate with other software development staff within the Wind Energy Department, in cross-sectional projects.

Our expectations of you
We are primarily using FORTRAN as compiled languages and Python as scripting languages, but we are looking for more skills from a successful applicant. We are seeking candidates that have the following required competences:
  • Background in Mechanical Engineering, Wind Energy or a physics based application field
  • Good knowledge of the Fortran syntax, the cross platform compilation environment and the numerical math libraries
  • Good knowledge of Python syntax and the scientific Python stack
  • Experience with software design, architecture and larger software projects

In addition, we expect you to have experience in several of the following technologies and scientific fields:
  • Version control of software (e.g., Git)
  • Build automation, automatic testing and continuous integration tools (e.g., Gitlab CI)
  • Coupling Python with compiled languages (f2py, cython, Pybind11, Boost.Python, SWIG)
  • C++, Matlab, and parallel programming with OpenMP/MPI
  • High performance computing on large-scale linux clusters and job scheduling systems (e.g. Slurm, LSF)
  • Containerization technology, e.g. Docker, Singularity
  • Shell scripting, e.g. Bash, Powershell
  • GUI and visualization (e.g. PyQt, OpenGL)
  • Optimization (OpenMDAO)
  • Databases and lab data protocols
  • Elasticity theory, structural mechanics and multibody dynamics simulations

Finally, we expect that you share our vision to strive for Wind Energy and its successful application in society are comfortably able to
  • Work independently and to efficiently deliver results on time
  • Work as part of a team in a multi-disciplinary environment
  • Take the initiative, prioritize and work under set deadlines
  • Communicate in English, both verbal and written

We offer
We offer an interesting and challenging job in an international atmosphere with the focus on research, teaching, innovation and scientific advice for the benefit of the surrounding community. We place emphasis on a high level of professionalism among our staff, so skills development is an integral part of our organization. We offer a great flexibility in the position. In the area of technical and natural sciences, DTU is one of the leading research and education institutions in Europe.

Salary and appointment terms
The appointment will be based on the collective agreement with the Danish Confederation of Professional Associations. The allowance will be agreed upon with the relevant union.

The workplace is DTU Risø Campus, Roskilde, Denmark.

Application and contact
Please submit your online application no later than 13 May 2022 (Danish time). Open the 'Apply online' link, fill out the form and attach your motivated application, CV and exam certificates.

If you would like additional information about the position, you are welcome to contact Head of Section Henrik Bredmose, phone +45 4525 4315 or e-mail: hbre@dtu.dk. mailto:kady@dtu.dk

You can read more about DTU Wind Energy at our homepage: www.vindenergi.dtu.dk/english.

Applications received after the deadline will not be considered.

All interested candidates irrespective of age, gender, race, disability, religion or ethnic background are encouraged to apply.

DTU Wind and Energy Systems has more than 330 staff members, including 180 academic staff members and approximately 75 PhD students. DTU Wind and Energy Systems has a considerable degree of innovation and cooperation with companies and sector associations within the wind industry in Denmark and abroad. The research is conducted within the three main topics wind energy systems, wind turbine technology, and basics for wind energy. DTU Wind and Energy Systems is one of the largest and most prominent research institutions within wind energy.

Technology for people
DTU develops technology for people. With our international elite research and study programmes, we are helping to create a better world and to solve the global challenges formulated in the UN's 17 Sustainable Development Goals. Hans Christian Ørsted founded DTU in 1829 with a clear vision to develop and create value using science and engineering to benefit society. That vision lives on today. DTU has 13,400 students and 5,800 employees. We work in an international atmosphere and have an inclusive, evolving, and informal working environment. DTU has campuses in all parts of Denmark and in Greenland, and we collaborate with the best universities around the world.
